div.head: To the judicious Reader.
div.p: AMongst tho≈øe infinite number of Pamphlets and Libells, wherewith this knowing I≈øland, to wit, the Citie and Countrey is pestered, and the ayre thereof infected and poy≈øoned with the ≈øulphurous breathings of their vanitie, prophanene≈ø≈øe and lyes, every houre producing ≈øomething new, ≈øomething wicked, ≈øomething fooli≈øh, little true: according to the ≈øeverall con≈øtitutions and di≈øpo≈øitions of the Climactericall men of this age, from tho≈øe hourely events and occurrences of per≈øons, things and times: There is one ignorant fooli≈øh wicked Pamphlet or Libell of the Roundheads lately Printed, receiving its mon≈øtrous prodigious and untimely birth from the wombe of an ignoramus. And the which Pamphlet or Libell, is as full of lyes and folly, as a beggar of lice and a dog of fleas: being the mo≈øt fal≈øe, fooli≈øh, and ignorant de≈øcription of the Roundheads: And hath occa≈øioned this ≈øhort di≈øcour≈øe following (in its due and full ≈øea≈øon) to ≈øtep forth in the clothing of a Pamphlet, to meet with fooles in their folly, And by good skill and ≈øtrength of armes to bray him in a Morter, till this ignoramus and his Pro≈øelytes be convinced and di≈øarmed of their ≈øordid, ≈øencele≈ø≈øe, and gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, in framing ≈øo fal≈øe and ≈øilly a de≈øcription, and applying the terme Roundhead to tho≈øe per≈øons whom there is not the lea≈øt ≈øhow of rea≈øon or hone≈øty to evince it.

The judicious Reader, is reque≈øted to behold really as in a gla≈ø≈øe the reall and true de≈øcription of a Roundhead indeed, and to whom it may properly with ≈øound and undeniable grounds and rea≈øons be applyed unto, according to the In≈øcription or Title of this ≈øhort di≈øcour≈øe: referring the whole matter in hand to thy wi≈ødome, judgement, and con≈øcience, ever re≈øting a reall Servant to all vertuous Readers,

div.head: THE SOVNDHEADS DESCRIPTION OF THE ROVNDHEAD, OR A Roundhead Anatomized in his Integralls or Excrementalls.
div.p: A Roundhead, according to the title or in≈øcription of this Di≈øcour≈øe (being the untying the fir≈øt knot) may be defined or expre≈ø≈øed in the≈øe twelve ≈øeverall Expre≈ø≈øions or Definitions.
There be the≈øe twelve ≈øeverall Definitions of a Roundhead, whereby all men may both know and ≈øee what and who he is.

div.head: A Roundhead in Rerum Natura is.

list.item: 1. A white bald ≈ømooth pate, under a Perriwigg of the newe≈øt fa≈øhion.
2. A ≈ømooth round bowle, ki≈ø≈øing his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øe in a long covered Bowling-alley.
3. A very tender thing, for it mu≈øt at noone-day weare a long furr'd Night cap.
4. That which onely appeares in the night in bed-chambers like a Gho≈øt, or Hobgoblin.
5. An Owle in an Ivie-bu≈øh, who cannot endure the light and ≈øight of truth and hone≈øty, as the Owle cannot behold the Sunne in the midday.

6. In a Circular motion all the day time, to≈ø≈øed up and downe like a Tennis-ball by the Racket of every foole, from one hazzard to another,
till it hath worne out all its bowels: That is, It is a Roundheaded Gentleman in his new Periwigg, his head and his wits running round, led and carried up and down by every foole from one mi≈øchiefe to another, till he hath worne out and lo≈øt all his wits and his money.
7. Is a Civit-catt with a long tayle, who is a perfumed odoriferous Perriwigd Roundhead.
9. The Counterfeit of a Holland Chee≈øe with a Map on his head.
10. A living skull wrapped up in a winding ≈øheet of dead mens excrements.

11. A ≈øtrange homebred Mon≈øter, carried up and downe in a little hou≈øe one ≈øtory high (by the learned called a Sedan) to a Play-hou≈øe, where any man may ≈øee him for twelve pence a peece upon the Stage.

12
One covered with a narrow brimmd hatt.
With a top-top-gallant crowne very flatt.
And a round blocke under that.
Well bu≈øhed and ≈øhagg'd downe to his backe.
And ≈øtrongly perfumed with Sacke.
While his braines doe ake and cracke.
And his tongue doth ≈øweare and chatt.
And cur≈øe his Brother Roundheads that.
Turned him into a Counter Ratt.

div.p:
The≈øe Twelve Definitions of a Roundhead, anatomize the Mon≈øter to be one who would be thought and called a Gentleman, when indeed he is one of the Raskally witles generation, or a bladder prepo≈øterou≈øly blowne up by the ≈øtinking breath of ≈øome windy brained foole, with a Peacocks feather in his hatt, vapouring and flouri≈øhing in the circle of his owne conceit, that he is a naturall Gentleman borne, when he is but an artificiall Wood≈øtreet or Poultrey-Counter-feit Gentleman at his be≈øt. This Superlative, admirable wonder (among children and fooles) is one that (par la fortune de la guerre) hath lo≈øt his naturall haire from his naturall head: and thereupon he is deprived of his naturall witts: his haire being newly gone, his witts went pre≈øently after a wooll-gathering, and along while ≈øcattered as fa≈øt as they gathered, till at length meeting with a deere and neere friend of his Gregory Scotch-mark, a mile beyond Holborne-hill, (a notable Mountebanke of approved skill in the cures of all di≈øea≈øes) who advi≈øeth him to ≈øome artificiali≈øts, whom he furni≈øheth with all the dead men and womens wooll of their heads, which comes under the ≈øhaying of his hands every Se≈ø≈øions, who being
of notable skill in the excrementall art, doe at the proper co≈øt and charges of this di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Gentleman, ≈øo compo≈øe, contract, and weave this wooll, that it is made an excellent covering to hang about his noddle, and then he becomes immediately at the fir≈øt putting on, and ≈øo forwards, an artificiall Gentleman Roundhead. And they pa≈ø≈øe and are e≈øteemed by many for Squires and Gentlemen, of no little wit, and furni≈øh the Arithmeticians of the age with figures and cyphers, whereby in the Arithmeticians accompt, they are reckoned and ca≈øt up in haire infinite, but in wit meere Cyphers.

div.head: 2. The reall Cau≈øes producing this Roundhead.
div.p: There are ≈øeverall cau≈øes in Nature, naturall cau≈øes, therefore according to our de≈øcription in the Title, we mu≈øt anatomize this Roundhead in his integralls and excrementalls, from his Round head to his round heele; the di≈øcu≈ø≈øion whereof will complete the cau≈øes producing this Roundhead.

div.head: For his Integralls in generall.
div.p: His ≈øoule and body throughout, in all and every part, his whole naturall frame and con≈øtitution (is for the pre≈øent) a rude, va≈øt, unpoli≈øhed Chaos of ≈øin & iniquitie, a per≈øon who is ≈øold under ≈øin, a ≈ølave and va≈ø≈øall to ≈øin, the Devill, the world, the fle≈øh, full of all darkne≈ø≈øe, corruption, and filth: being mo≈øt contrary & abominable to all beauty, light, goodnes, libertie, and ≈øweetne≈ø≈øe: So that where there is ≈øo univer≈øall a contagion and confu≈øion, ≈øuch a lepro≈øie of iniquitie, throughout and all over, it mu≈øt needs follow undeniably, that here is ≈øufficient matter for the producing of this round-headed Mon≈øter. As will more con≈øpicuou≈øly appeare in the particular anatomizing, or embowelling of this Mon≈øter in his Integralls.

Fir≈øt, He is a per≈øon who≈øe heart is filled with all manner of prophanene≈ø≈øe, ba≈øene≈ø≈øe, and wickedne≈ø≈øe, as pride, uncleanne≈ø≈øe, adultery, fornication, idolatry, ≈øuper≈øtition, athei≈øme, hardne≈ø≈øe of heart, hatred, envy, full of all deceitfulne≈ø≈øe, lves, fal≈øhood, evill thoughts, purpo≈øes, intents full of trea≈øons and con≈øpiracies, again≈øt all that is pure good, holy, heavenly, and ≈øpirituall, witne≈ø≈øe the very con≈øciences of the Roundheads them≈øelves, if they will looke into them, and but heare and ≈øuffer them to ≈øpeake.

Secondly, He is a per≈øon who≈øe mind and intellectuall part is full of blindne≈ø≈øe, darknes, ≈øimplicitie & gro≈ø≈øe ignorance, yea palpable gro≈ø≈øe thick darkne≈ø≈øe, that may be felt, yea wilfull blindne≈ø≈øe: knowing nothing in any di≈øtinct manner of God, or of goodnes, of vertue, or them≈øelves,
but yet ≈øtrongly per≈øwaded and conceited in the imagination of their own evill heart (formerly de≈øcribed) of their owne wi≈ødome, goodne≈ø≈øe, and vertue: And for the proofe of this, witne≈ø≈øe all their Pamphlets, all their di≈øcour≈øes, all their railings, cur≈øings and ≈ølanders, from day to day. Their Pamphlets, filld with nothing but prophane, fooli≈øh, uncleane words and expre≈ø≈øions, there being nothing ≈øub≈øtantiall or wi≈øe according to truth in them: Their di≈øcour≈øes being irrationall, ≈øimple, ≈øhallow, blind, yea ≈øotti≈øhly ignorant, profe≈ø≈øing them≈øelves wi≈øe, and yet knowing nothing (at lea≈øt wi≈øe as they ought to know) as the Wi≈øe man in the Proverbs 28 Chap. 5. ver. proves in the≈øe words; Evill men under≈øtand not judgement, but they that ≈øeeke the Lord under≈øtand all things: They are fooli≈øhly and wickedly ignorant: They in their di≈øcour≈øes brag of learning, parts, wits, knowledge, but they are ignorant and under≈øtand not Religion, vertue, manners: It hath been as often proved as there be houres in the day, minutes in each houre: That the≈øe Roundheads (according to the former de≈øcription, who are the Roundheads indeed in rerum natura) when they have been in di≈øpute and rea≈øoning with tho≈øe whom they and their pro≈øelytes formerly fal≈øly called by the name of Roundheads, who are indeed tho≈øe whom the Wi≈øe man in the place aforecited, called Seekers of God, and who under≈øtand all things: I ≈øay, they have not been able to make a rationall or true an≈øwer to Que≈øtions demanded them, nor defend any argument of their owne from being torne in pieces, or vani≈øhing into ≈ømoake and ayre; but they have been forced like Ignoramus him≈øelfe, to hold their peace and learne wit: or if ≈øhame and di≈øgrace troubled them, then when they wanted wit to make a rationall an≈øwer, then to be ≈øure their gracele≈ø≈øe hearts and tongues did not want cur≈øes, lyes, oaths, ≈ølanders and railing.
3. For his body, both integralls and excrementalls, ≈øee the cau≈øes producing a Roundhead:

He is one who≈øe head and braines is elevated with Sack, ≈øtrong drink, and Tobacco, who≈øe eyes are full of adultery, his face with patches and plai≈øters, or ≈øome of his Ladies favour-≈øports: his whole body is embalmed to pre≈øerve his rotten carka≈øe from offending the no≈øtrills of his friends and companions; or el≈øe his face is full of skarrs, cuts and wounds, in quarrells with brothers of his owne Tribe, when they cannot agree in ≈øwearing and lying.
His no≈øe if not falne downe flat dead on his face already, yet it is to be feared, it cannot ≈øtand upright long.

His tongue may be compared to the Devill, yea hell it ≈øelfe, breathing
forth nothing but oaths, cur≈øes, railings, bawdry every moment.

His hands and feet ever in one quarrell or other, or employed in ≈øome brothell-hou≈øe in the lu≈øtfull embraces and helli≈øh cla≈øpings of ≈øome of his filthy and uncleane Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and whori≈øh Ladies, till he returnes home lame full of the heavy di≈øea≈øe by the vulgar ≈øort called the Poxe. And thus you have the Integralls of this Roundhead de≈øcribed, from the particular cau≈øes producing a Roundhead, which in plaine termes and few words is this: The evill heart & manners of the≈øe men bring them to the Poxe, the Poxe eates of their naturall haire, and ≈øo they become Roundheads.

And thus went the haire away, the Gentleman becomes bald, his witts here going fir≈øt away, and a very little returning to him (upon the cure in part wrought) he con≈øults with the artificiali≈øts and excrementalli≈øts of the time, that he may bring up a new fa≈øhion to make Perriwigd Gentlemen.
And ≈øo we pa≈ø≈øe to the untying of the third knot, which is,

div.head: 3. The reall properties and peculiarities of a Roundhead, whereby he may be notoriou≈øly knowne and ≈øeene by any judicious ob≈øervant eye.
div.p: And the≈øe properties are not a few, but ≈øo many as we ≈øhall really collect and compri≈øe within the compa≈ø≈øe of this ≈øhort Di≈øcour≈øe, we ≈øhall endeavour to give the world information of.
The Gentleman Roundhead being now created and formed by tho≈øe former producing cau≈øes; now you ≈øhall ≈øee him fa≈øhioned in all his excrementall perfections.
The which, I will compri≈øe under the≈øe five heads, and ≈øo fini≈øh the Di≈øcour≈øe.

list.item:
He may be de≈øcribed
1. By his cloathing.
2. By his po≈øture.
3. By his di≈øcour≈øe or language.
4. By his a≈ø≈øociates, and his ba≈øtard brood.
5. By his actions.

div.p: Fir≈øt, for his clothing, a ≈øingular property, he loves rich clothing, and borrowes of all Nations a ≈øeverall dre≈ø≈øe & attire, he hath infinite mind for change of rayment, as the haires of his Perriwig be infinite and pa≈øt numbering.

Therefore we mu≈øt begin to reckon from the fir≈øt artificiall haire in his Perriwig, to the la≈øt artificiall ≈øtitch in the ≈øoale of his Bootes: hold, hold, hold, what have we ≈øaid, we mu≈øt begin there, we mu≈øt give our
≈øelves a ju≈øt correction, we doe take a cubit from his ≈øtature at lea≈øt, and detract from one of his greate≈øt perfections, by making a dwarfe of a proper Gentleman. And our mi≈øtake would have been ≈øo gro≈ø≈øe, (if we had not ≈øpeedily collected and corrected our thoughts) as to have undertaken to have given the de≈øcription of the height of Pauls onely by relating the height of the Church, when wee ≈øhould de≈øcribe the height of Pauls by the Steeple: But having timely corrected our thoughts wee ≈øhall endeavour to begin at the height and top of this Roundheaded Gentlemans perfection: (Onely a little by the way ob≈øerve it as one of his chiefe≈øt properties, that he loves and prides to be clothed with the newe≈øt fa≈øhion. And therefore he is full of invention, and his thoughts multiplicious and fruitfull, how he may have change of attire and fa≈øhion: yea rather then he will want any one fa≈øhion, he will ≈øo contrive by the advice of his grand and little and nimble councell, the profe≈ø≈øors of the cro≈ø≈øelegd art, who are very dexterous in the compo≈øure of all fa≈øhions contracted and united in one, that this Roundhead being clothed in his new trappings, he is made the repre≈øentative body of all kindreds, tongues, and nations, his Roundhead confining his braines in ≈øuch a circle, that they run round about the Globed Center for every new ≈øtrange fa≈øhion.)

Fir≈øt therefore for his hatt, it is fa≈øhioned like the blocke on which it was ≈øquared, being flat crowned, and not made fit to his head, but to his Perriwigg, and therefore it ≈øets to his Perriwigg as loo≈øe, as his Perriwigg to his bald pate, (unle≈ø≈øe it be tyed) ready to fall off to the right hand or to the left, to ≈øalute his brother Roundhead when he meets him: And wee know the rea≈øon of this fa≈øhion, becau≈øe the≈øe Gallants de≈øire and love to have their witts and heads at libertie, and cannot endure to have their braines bound too fa≈øt, or confined in their noddles.

Next, their hatt is narrow-brimd, & they have a good rea≈øon for that, for whereas the ignorant ≈øort object again≈øt it, as unprofitable, yea prejudiciall, for it expo≈øes their bodies to the weather, They give a ≈øudden an≈øwer to this Objection, and prove the contrary, That a good bu≈øh doth ≈øhelter them better from the weather, with which they are largely furni≈øhed. But that we may not forget to hang forth our Colours on the Flag-≈øtaffe before we come downe from the maine top, we mu≈øt therefore ≈øet out a very faire feather, tyed fa≈øt with Ribbins of all colours in the Rainebow. He is no true Gentleman without a feather in his cap, and he is no man of warre without his colours. Therefore that
he may have and claime the propertie both of Souldier and Gentleman, he will be well feathered.

q.l: What is lighter then a feather?

div.p: For his Perriwigg the chiefe≈øt jewell about him, being artificially woven and bound together, ≈øtrongly perfumed, a right colour to a haire it is, which he borrowes from ≈øeverall dead men and women, a haire from one, and a haire from a ≈øecond, and ≈øo forward, that he is exceedingly ingaged to them for every haire of his head. As for the re≈øt of his clothing downwards, To wit, his Band with buttons and loopes under his chin, to the confu≈øion of all Band-≈øtring-makers, with his ≈øhort wa≈øted dublet, long ≈øword, and long breeches, ≈øhort bootes and thundering ≈øpurres, being all compo≈øed according to the Rules of are and rea≈øon, for every ≈øtitch of him: The particulars of the recitall, would be too tedious and prolixe for this ≈øhort Di≈øcour≈øe, and therefore is purpo≈øely omitted at pre≈øent: Becau≈øe wee de≈øire to proceed to the next property of this Roundhead.

2. By his Po≈øture: An admirable po≈øture he hath, he alwayes in ≈øtead of ≈øtanding in a po≈øture of defence, is ever in a po≈øture of offence, he barkes and bites, and ≈ønaps every one that comes neere him, that are not of his owne con≈øtitution. His very lookes ≈øtrike fooles with terrour and amazement, his patches and ≈øpotts on his face, are the en≈øigne that he is a Souldier and a man of offence every inch and ≈øtitch of him: His lookes are ≈øo big and terrible, having ≈øuch a Maje≈øty in them as is able to make children run away, as if ≈øome ≈øtrange apparition appeared to them of Jack a Dandy, or as if ≈øome Bullbeggar, or Buggbeare were readie to eate them up: And indeed their long Perriwigs are like ≈øo many vi≈ø≈øards of ugly ≈øhapes and repre≈øentations, to skare and fright children and fooles into good manners: And is not this now a ≈øingular propertie and vertue in them, that they are able by the very Maje≈øtie and dreadfulne≈ø≈øe of their a≈øpect, to worke ≈øuch cures as that children and fooles ≈øhould ≈øtand in feare of them, and be ruled and skared into wit and manners.
